snippet: Thrill-seeking bees that fearlessly leave their hives and search for new sources of food and hive locations have genetic brain patterns that set them apart from more timid bees, a new study suggests.
abstract: Study in journal Science finds that 'scout' honeybees, who leave the hive to seek out new food and hive locations, have genetic brain patterns that set them apart from other bees.
lead_paragraph: Thrill-seeking bees that fearlessly leave their hives and search for new sources of food and hive locations have genetic brain patterns that set them apart from more timid bees, a new study suggests.

headline.print_headline: Brains of Bee Scouts Are Wired for Adventure
headline.main: Brains of Bee Scouts Are Wired for Adventure
